Edit: Does anybody know why all (non military) planes spool up their engines in 2 steps?

From what I have read, older engines (60's-80's) had problems with temperature of parts, and had to run at half throttle to warm up evenly.

Also, engine thrust is a function like product of itself, and thrust thus is exponential. This means that an engine just sliiiightly more powered at low revs will get full thrust some seconds earlier, and this leads to uneven thrust and going off the runway. That's why engines are set to 50% revs to nivel this difference.
